module.name: observ
module.description:
Observ-OM is a model to uniformly describe any phenotypic, genotypic or molecular observation. The five core concepts are:
ObservationTarget: the object we are observing.
For example: an Individual, a Panel/Strain, a Sample, a Gene, a Marker.
ObservableFeature: the question asked or characteristic being oberveded.
For example: 'What is height of [Target]?', 'What is genotype of [Target] at [Marker]?', 'Has [Target] ever used medicine [X]', 'What is QTL p-value association of [Marker] with [Gene Expression]?
Protocol: the procedure of observation
For example: Food Frequency Questionnaire (FFQ), R/QTL mapping method, Genotype array, GWAS protocol.
ProtocolApplication: the actual act of observation. For example: 'FFQ asked to [Individual:individual1], 'R/QTL applied to [Marker:pvv4]', 'Genotype array applied to [Panel:Mouse RIL BxD 1]
ObservedValue: the values for each feature observed, grouped per ProtocolApplication(and thereby target)

entity.name: ObservableFeature
entity.description:
ObservableFeature defines anything that can be observed in a phenotypic Investigation.
In other words, ObservableFeature are the questions asked, e.g. 'What is Height?', 'What is Systolic blood pressure?', or 'Has blue eyes?'.
Some questions may be repeated for multiple characteristics. For example 'What is [MarkerAllele] observed?' can be applied to all elements of a Marker set, and 'What is [medicin codes] uses' can be applied to a set of Medicine codes. This can be specified using the measuredCharacteristic field. (Discussion: how exactly?)
The identifier of ObservableFeature is unique . It is recommended that each ObservableFeature is named according to a well-defined ontology term which can be specified via ontologyReference. The ObservableFeature class maps to XGAP:Trait, METABASE:Question, FuGE:DimensionElement, and PaGE:ObservableFeature. Multi-value features can be grouped by Protocol. For instance: high blood pressure can be inferred from observations for features systolic and diastolic blood pressure. There may be many alternative protocols to measure a feature. See Protocol section.

field.name: unit
field.description: (Optional) Reference to the well-defined measurement unit used to observe this feature (if feature is that concrete). E.g. mmHg

field.name: dataType
field.description: (Optional) Reference to the technical data type. E.g. 'int'

field.name: temporal
field.description: Whether this feature is time dependent and can have different values when measured on different times (e.g. weight, temporal=true) or generally only measured once (e.g. birth date, temporal=false)

field.name: description
field.description: (Optional) Rudimentary meta data about the observable feature. Use of ontology terms references to establish unambigious descriptions is recommended

entity.name: PermittedValue
entity.description: PermittedValue is partOf ObservableFeature to define permitted values for an ObservableFeature, such as the categorical answer codes that are often used in Questionaires. For example the Measurement 'sex' has {code_string = 1, label=male} and {code_string = 2, label=female}. PermittedValue can be linked to well-defined ontology terms via the ontologyReference. Category extends ObservationElement such that it can be referenced by ObservedValue.value. The Category class maps to METABASE::Category

field.name: valueForFeature
field.description: The ObservableFeature these permitted values are part of.

field.name: valueCode
field.description: The value used to store this category in ObservedValue. For example '1', '2'.

field.name: valueLabel
field.description: User friendly textual representation of this value. For example : 'male', 'female'

field.name: valueDescription
field.description: Description of the code. Use of ontology terms references to establish unambigious descriptions is recommended

field.name: isMissing
field.description: whether this value should be treated as missing value.

field.name: ontologyReference
field.description: (Optional) Reference to the formal ontology definition for this code.

entity.name: Characteristic
entity.description: Characteristics are yes-no statements about properties of an object. These can be used as part of an observation, as parameter of ObservableFeature ('measuredCharacteristic'). For example: 'What is allele of [Marker]', here the [Marker] is a characteristic. Also, Characteristics can be used as target of observation. Typical examples are 'Individual' or 'Panel'. But also 'Marker' can be an Target when asked the question 'QTL p-value for [phenotype]': here both target and feature are characteristic, for example 'leave count' (phenotype characteristic) and 'PVV4' (marker characteristic).

unique.description: identifier is unique across all Characteristic (and its subclasses)

entity.name: ObservationTarget
entity.description: ObservationTarget defines the subjects of observation. For instance: 'target 1' IS A 'Individual'. The ObservationTarget class maps to XGAP:Subject, METABASE:Patient and maps to Page:Abstract_Observation_Target. The identifier of observationTargets is unique.

entity.name: Protocol
entity.description:
The Protocol class defines parameterizable descriptions of (analysis)methods; each protocol has a unique identifier. The usage of a protocol is called 'ProtocolApplication', which is the application of a protocol to one target (this typically translates to a data row in a table).Examples of protocols are: SOP for blood pressure measurement used by UK biobank, or 'R/qtl' as protocol for statistical analysis. Protocol is a high level object that represents the details of protocols used during the investigation. Protocol has an association to OntologyTerm to represent the type of protocol.
The FUGE equivalent to Protocol is FuGE::Protocol.
The Protocol class maps to FuGE/XGAP/MageTab Protocol, but in contrast to FuGE it is not required to extend protocol before use. The Protocol class also maps to METABASE:Form (note that components are solved during METABASE:Visit which can be nested). Has no equivalent in PaGE.

field.name: ProtocolType
field.description: classification of protocol

field.name: Description
field.description: Description, or reference to a description, of the protocol

field.name: TargetType
field.description: Filter string to find suitable targets for this protocol. Should be an xref?

field.name: Parameters
field.description: parameters (in/out) that are used or produced by this protocol.

field.name: Contact
field.description: Contact person for this protocol. TODO: Check if there can be multiple contacts.

entity.name: ProtocolApplication
entity.description:
A ProtocolApplication class defines the actual action of observation using a protocol. For example: the action of blood pressure measurement on 1000 individuals, using a particular protocol, resulting in 1000 associated observed values. Optionally, protocolApplication can be grouped into a DataSet (which can in turn be part of an Experiment).
The ProtocolApplication class maps to FuGE/XGAP ProtocolApplication, but in FuGE ProtocolApplications can take Material or Data (or both) as input and produce Material or Data (or both) as output. Similar to PaGE.ObservationMethod. Maps to METABASE:Visit (also note that METABASE:PlannedVisit allows for planning of protocol applications; this is outside scope for this model?).

field.name: Target
field.description: References the ObservationTarget that was observed using this protocol. For example 'individual1'. In a correlation matrix this could be also a characteristic such as 'probe123'.

field.name: protocolUsed
field.description: Reference to the protocol that is being used.

field.name: startTime
field.description: time when the protocol started.

field.name: endTime
field.description: (Optional) time when the protocol ended.

field.name: partOfDataSet
field.description: (Optional) DataSet this data is part of.

field.name: Performers
field.description: (Optional)Persons involved in this protocol

entity.name: Observation
entity.description:
Generic model for observations, that is, the observed value on a feature-target pair given a protocol. See the 'data' package for all kinds of observations. Typically, this data is visualized in a spreadsheet format having rows (targets) and columns (features). Use cases that need support are:
Simple text/int values, e.g. 'length in cm (row; observableFeature) of individual1 (col; observationTarget) = 179 (value). These can be stored in subclass 'ObservedValue'
Relationship values, e.g. 'individual 1(row:observationtarget) and individual2 (col:observationtarget) = brothers (value:observabvlefeature). These can be stored in subclass 'ObservedValue'
Categoryd values, e.g. 'invidual 1 (row) and feature 'sex' (col) = 'male' (value; reference to code or ontology. These can be stored in subclass 'ObservedValue'
Data file values, e.g., 'aligned.bam' or 'plink imputed' (feature). These can be stored in subclass DataFile
Data matrices, e.g. 'qtlProfile' (feature) for 'bxd panel' (target). These can be stored in subclass ObservedData
Measurements are typically grouped by the protocol used, therefore a link to protocol application is added.
Implementation wise, the data may or may not be stored in the database directly. This is an optimization strategy independent of this generic structure. This structure is born out of the merger of Pheno-OM, XGAP and MAGE-TAB.

field.name: protocolApplication
field.description: Reference to the protocol application that was used to produce this observation. For example a particular patient visit or the application of a microarray or the calculation of a QTL model

field.name: Feature
field.description: References the ObservableFeature that this observation was made on. For example 'probe123'.

field.name: characteristic
field.description: (Optional: If protocol.observedCharacteristic != null). For example to a 'Is brother of [charaacteristic]'

module.entity:
Generic storage of values. Values can be atomatic observations, e.g., length (feature) of individual 1 (protocolApplication.target) = 179cm (value). Values can also be qualified by some characteristic, e.g., QTL p-value (feature) between phenotype 'leaf count' (characteristic) and marker 'PVV4' (protocolApplication.target) = 0.1^10+3 (value).
Discussion: how to model sample pooling in this model?
More Discussion: do we want to have type specific subclasses? No, because you can solve this by casting during querying?

entity.name: FeatureAnnotation
entity.description: Enable the adding of annotations to a feature and indicate if the annotation is perfect description

entity.name: Species
entity.description: Ontology terms for species. E.g. Arabidopsis thaliana. DISCUSSION: should we avoid subclasses of OntologyTerm and instead make a 'tag' filter on terms so we can make pulldowns context dependent (e.g. to only show particular subqueries of ontologies).

entity.name: Individual
entity.description: The Individuals class defines the subjects that are used as observation target. The Individual class maps to XGAP:Individual and PaGE:Individual. Groups of individuals can be defined via Panel.

field.name: Mother
field.description: Refers to the mother of the individual.

field.name: Father
field.description: Refers to the father of the individual.

entity.name: Panel
entity.description: The Panel class defines groups of individuals based on cohort design, case/controls, families, etc. For instance: 'LifeLines cohort', 'middle aged man', 'recombinant mouse inbred Line dba x b6' or 'Smith family'. A Panel can act as a single ObservationTarget. For example: average height (Measurement) in the LifeLines cohort (Panel) is 174cm (ObservedValue). The Panel class maps to XGAP:Strain and PaGE:Panel classes. In METABASE this is assumed there is one panel per study.

field.name: PanelType
field.description: Indicate the type of Panel (example: Sample panel, AssayedPanel, Natural=wild type, Parental=parents of a cross, F1=First generation of cross, RCC=Recombinant congenic, CSS=chromosome substitution)

field.name: Species
field.description: The species this panel is an instance of/part of/extracted from.

field.name: Individuals
field.description: The list of individuals in this panel

entity.name: PanelSource
entity.description: PanelSources is partOf Panel to define how panels are related panels, founder panels, such as overlap, selection criteria, getting assayed panel from a sample panel, etc.

field.name: CurrentPanel
field.description: Panel for which these sources are defined.

field.name: SourcePanel
field.description: Source that contributed individuals to current panel

field.name: NumberOfIndividuals
field.description: Number of individuals lifted over from this source

field.name: SelectionCriteria
field.description: Inclusion/exclusion criteria used to select these individuals from source into current panel
